intro: Campanula sibirica var. pannonica, commonly known as the Pannonian bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Central and Eastern Europe. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems covered in fine, hairy pubescence. The plant produces clusters of bell-shaped, blue to violet flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lanceolate, serrated, and arranged alternately along the stem. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in meadows, grasslands, and rocky areas.
